title-group.article-title: Participation and Reflective Distance: The End of Laurence Sterne's "A Sentimental Journey" and the Resistance to Doctrine

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1997 University of Notre Dame English Department

ref.mixed-citation: (Sermons 2: 86).
Tristram, "that he feared God, and reverenced religion" (179; vol. 3, ch. 41).
Aristotle, de Interpretation (17a)

Tristram says: "Here a Devil of a rap at the door snapp'd my father's definition (like his tobacco-pipe) in two,--and, at the same time, crushed the head of as notable and curious a dissertation as ever was engendered in the womb of speculation;--it was some months before my father could get an opportunity to be safely deliver'd of it" (78; vol. 2, ch. 7; emphasis mine).
Ricoeur (2: 23-25)

Locke on language: "Man, therefore, had by nature his organs so fashioned as to be fit to frame articulate sounds, which we call words. But this was not enough to produce language; for parrots and several other birds will be taught to make articulate sounds enough, which yet by no means are capable of language" (2: 3; bk. 3, ch. 1.1).
Voegelin, The Ecumenic Age, ch. 5.
Tristram Shandy (94-106; vol. 2, ch. 17).
Sterne in Tristram Shandy invokes the "Gentle Spirit ... of my beloved CERVANTES" (482; vol. 9, ch. 24).
